payload.posterTitle: Antarctica: Peaks, Pack Ice, and the White Horizon

biomes.name: Antarctic Peninsula
biomes.description: The Antarctic Peninsula is a rugged edge of Antarctica with fjords, glaciers, and busy wildlife coasts. In summer, penguins nest near ice and rock while whales and seals feed offshore.

biomes.name: Transantarctic Mountains
biomes.description: The Transantarctic Mountains cut across Antarctica, dividing huge ice sheets. Sharp peaks, dry valleys, and wind‑scoured rock show a stark world where cold and time do most of the work.

biomes.name: Lambert Glacier
biomes.description: Lambert Glacier is a giant river of ice in East Antarctica. It drains a huge area of the ice sheet and slowly flows toward the coast, feeding the Amery Ice Shelf.

biomes.name: Vinson Massif
biomes.description: Vinson Massif is Antarctica’s highest mountain. Its steep, icy slopes rise above a vast white wilderness, where extreme cold, wind, and endless snow make every step a serious challenge.

biomes.name: Weddell Sea
biomes.description: The Weddell Sea is known for thick pack ice and massive icebergs. Along the shifting ice edge, seals, penguins, and whales find food in cold, nutrient‑rich water.

biomes.name: Antarctic Plateau
biomes.description: Antarctica’s plateau is a high, dry desert of ice near the continent’s center. It is flat, brutal, and incredibly cold, with clear skies and long stretches of silence.

biomes.name: South Georgia Island
biomes.description: South Georgia is a sub‑Antarctic island of glaciers and steep mountains. Its beaches swarm with king penguins and seals, making it one of the loudest and richest wildlife coasts on Earth.
